thread.title: Daylight Saving Time 2015: When does the clock 'fall back' an hour?
thread.title_full: Daylight Saving Time 2015: When does the clock 'fall back' an hour? | Examiner.com

author: Roz Zurko
title: Daylight Saving Time 2015: When does the clock 'fall back' an hour?
text:
Daylight Saving Time 2015 or Daylight Savings Time 2015: Which is it? When will the clocks "fall back" in 2015? Getty archived image With summer officially over, “Daylight Savings Time 2015” and “Daylight Saving Time 2015” looks to be a trending topic online with folks wondering when the clocks are due to “ fall back .” The days are getting shorter as darkness creeps in during dinnertime for many today. Folks are looking for the time change that happens this time of year.
According to the Christian Post on October 1, this biannual practice of moving the clock ahead or dropping it behind an hour is in place thanks to the 2005 Energy Policy Act. The actual terminology is “Daylight Saving Time,” but “Daylight Savings Times” is also an acceptable term in other areas of the world and it's becoming quite the norm when doing a search through “Google News.”
In the U.S. Daylight Saving Time begins on the second Sunday in March at 2 a.m. and it ends on the first Sunday in November at 3a.m. For 2015, that day will be Sunday, November 1.
While most of the U.S. observes Daylight Saving Time, Hawaii and a good majority of the area of Arizona keep their clocks the same all year. They don't participate in changing the clock twice a year, according to MNR Daily,
In Europe, Daylight Saving Time ends earlier than in the United States. Their Daylight Saving Time officially started on March 29, 2015 and will end on Oct. 25, 2015 at 3 a.m. which also falls on a Sunday.
Australia also recognizes Daylight Savings Time , where they use "savings" in their terminology. Because they are on the other side of he world, they are just opposite of the U.S., as their Daylight Savings Time starts pretty close to the time the U.S. is ending theirs. In Australia Daylight Savings Time will officially start on, Oct. 4, 2015 at 2 am, when they put their clock an hour ahead.
According to Time and Date.com : “'Daylight Savings Time' is very commonly used, especially in Australia, Canada and the United States. It's likely that the incorrect term 'savings' entered is popular vocabulary because it's so often used in everyday contexts, like 'savings account'”.
